title: Hospitality suffers half of all job losses since Reeves’s Budget
description: Britain’s pub and restaurants have suffered more than half of all jobs losses in Britain since Rachel Reeves’s £25bn Budget tax raid, the industry has warned.
content:
Britain’s pub and restaurants have suffered more than half of all jobs losses in Britain since Rachel Reeves’s £25bn Budget tax raid, the industry has warned.

Almost 90,000 jobs have been lost in the hospitality sector since the Chancellor’s increase to employer taxes last October, equal to 53pc of the 165,000 roles which have gone across all industries, according to trade group UKHospitality.

It means one in every 25 jobs in pubs, bars, hotels, cafes and restaurants have been lost, leaving customers with fewer serving staff and putting increased pressure on existing workers during busy periods.

UKHospitality said the figures indicated the blow from the tax increase was far worse than the 50,000 job losses forecasted by the Office for Budget Responsibility.

Hospitality is particularly vulnerable to Ms Reeves’s changes to National Insurance contributions (NICs) because the increase in the tax rate from 13.8pc to 15pc was accompanied by a cut to the annual earnings threshold at which it applies.

By cutting the point at which the levy kicks in from £9,100 per year to £5,000, the Chancellor applied the tax to more of the low-paid and part-time staff on which bars and eateries depend.

The prospects for the industry are worsening because of the higher costs of keeping more staff on the payroll.

There were 73,000 job vacancies in accommodation and food services in the three months to July, according to the Office for National Statistics.

That is down by one fifth from before the Budget, and is the fewest since the Covid lockdowns of 2020 and 2021, when much of the industry was forced to close its doors.

Excluding the pandemic, it represents the fewest vacancies since 2014, when the economy was still recovering from the long hangover of the financial crisis.

Kate Nicholls, chairman of UKHospitality, said the figures underlined the scale of the harm caused by the record tax rises imposed by Labour in its first year of government.

“The number of job losses suffered in hospitality since the Budget is staggering,” she said.

“More than half of all job losses since October occurring in hospitality is further evidence that our sector has been by far the hardest hit by the Government’s regressive tax increases.”

She said companies are cutting back on staff, as well as on opening hours and investment. “The sheer scale of costs being placed upon hospitality has forced businesses to take agonisingly tough decisions to cut jobs – with part-time and flexible roles often those most at risk,” she added

As a result, UKHospitality has called on the Chancellor to reverse the “devastating” raids to try to revive the economy. The trade group wants lower business rates, a change to NICs and cuts to VAT paid on food and drink.
summary: Almost 90,000 jobs have been lost in the hospitality sector since Rachel Reeves’ £25bn Budget tax raid, according to trade group UKHospitality. This equates to 53% of the total roles lost across all industries. The increase in the tax rate from 13.8pc to 15pc was accompanied by a cut to the annual earnings threshold at which it applies. This means one in every 25 jobs in pubs, bars, hotels, cafes and restaurants have been permanently lost, increasing pressure on existing workers during busy periods. The industry has called on Chancellor to reverse these "devastating" tax increases to revive the economy.
shortSummary: Britain’s hospitality sector has suffered over half of all job losses since Chancellor Rachel Reeves’ £25bn Budget tax increase, impacting businesses significantly.
argos_summary: Since Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s £25bn Budget tax raid, Britain’s hospitality sector has lost almost 90,000 jobs—over half of all job losses nationwide—due to a rise in employer National Insurance contributions from 13.8% to 15% and a lowered earnings threshold. The tax increase hit low‑paid and part‑time staff, forcing many pubs, bars, hotels, cafes and restaurants to cut staff, hours and investment. Vacancy rates in accommodation and food services have fallen to the lowest level since the COVID lockdowns, underscoring the sector’s struggle. UKHospitality calls for the Chancellor to reverse the tax hikes, lower business rates, adjust NICs and cut VAT on food and drink to revive the industry.
